description: From Middle English polishen, from Old French poliss-, stem of some of the conjugated forms of polir, from Latin polīre (“to polish, make smooth”), from Proto-Indo-European *pelh₂- (“to drive, strike, thrust”), from the notion of fulling cloth.

examples: A good silver polish will remove tarnish easily.
The floor was waxed to a high polish.

entries.meaning: Refinement; cleanliness in performance or presentation.
examples: The lecturer showed a lot of polish at his last talk.

verbs.description: polish (third-person singular simple present polishes, present participle polishing, simple past and past participle polished)

entries.meaning: (transitive) To shine; to make a surface very smooth or shiny by rubbing, cleaning, or grinding.
examples: He polished up the chrome until it gleamed.
The band has polished its performance since the last concert.

entries.meaning: (transitive) To apply shoe polish to shoes.
(intransitive) To become smooth, as from friction; to receive a gloss; to take a smooth and glossy surface.
(transitive) To refine; to wear off the rudeness, coarseness, or rusticity of; to make elegant and polite.
